PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is necessary to: (i) review the 
technical, environmental, economic and financial viability of the project and ascertain the project 
rationale, scope, cost, schedule, implementation arrangements, risks and mitigation measures; 
(ii) ensure the compliance with Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) safeguard policy statement 
(2009)  and  identify  mitigation  measures  and  institutional  strengthening;  and  (iii)  assist  the 
project executing agency in advance contracting for the ensuing project. 
 
2.  The PPTA is necessary as:  
(i)  the investment program is urgently needed in the Kyrgyz Republic; 
(ii)  the feasibility study to process the project is required; and 
(iii)  expertise  of  competent  international  and  national  consultants  is  needed  to 
prepare the project considering its technical complexity and scale. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
3.  Under  the  PPTA,  ADB  will  employ  a  consulting  firm  to  (i)  update  the  capacity 
assessment  of  the  executing  agency  (EA);  (ii)  conduct  technical,  economic,  financial  due 
diligence for rehabilitation of Uch Kurgan hydropower plant, sedimentation excavation and dam 
civil structure repair (including bridge) and the proposed small HPP, (hereafter “subprojects”); 
(iii) assist EA to prepare the environmental impact assessment (EIA) or initial environmental 
examination (IEE)  report, and/or Land Acquisition and Resettlement plan (if required); (iv) 
prepare technical specifications for the physical components; (v) provide inputs to ADB’s Report 
and Recommendation of the President; and (vi) assist executing agency in the preparation of 
bidding documents and bidding process. Individual national consultants will be hired to assess 
social development and gender aspects of the project and to support the executing agency to 
recruit project implementation consultant. The major outputs and activities are summarized in 
Table A3.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
5.  The technical assistance is estimated to cost $1,100,000 which will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-VI). All disbursements under 
the  PPTA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  government  will  provide  $100,000 
equivalent as counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, provision of office space and 
furniture. The detailed cost estimate is in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
6.  A total of 37 international person-months and 14 national person-months of consulting 
services will be required under the PPTA (Table A3.3) through a consulting firm. The firm will 
undertake  project  due  diligence,  prepare  feasibility  reports  required  by  the  government, 
safeguards reports and draft bidding documents. The firm will be recruited using the quality and 
cost-based selection  method  using  90/10  technical/financial  weighting  to  ensure  high  level 
quality outputs for the project. The proposal will be a full technical proposal. All consultants will 
be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, 
as amended from time to time). The Team  Leader is a key expert and will be a full-time 
employee of the firm. Firms may propose alternative person-month allotments with justifications.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
7.  Open Joint-Stock Company Electric Power Plants will be the EA for the PPTA.  The 
existing project implementation unit will implement the project. The EA will provide support to 
the consultants which includes: (i) arranging meetings with relevant government stakeholders 
and site visits, (ii) providing access to all relevant data and maps, and (iii) providing a suitably

furnished office (desks, office chairs, book shelves/cabinets adequate to accommodate the full 
complement of international and local consultants) with utilities and telecommunication access 
(national and international telephone lines, electricity and air conditioning/heating, and internet 
connections).  The consultants will be responsible for personal computers and other facilities for 
producing reports. Disbursements under the PPTA will follow the ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). Local expertise may be 
provided  by  a  competent  local  design  institute  through  subcontracting  arrangements  in 
preparation for government feasibility study.
